text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Wednesday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Parliament showed President Algirdas Brazauskas once again who rules the country. Parliament stripped the president of the right to suggest a candidate for new prosecutor general.
- The Baltic states will never be members of NATO, said Russian Communist leader, Gennady Zyuganov, to the newspaper during his visit in Washington to the national press club.
- Parliament left to the government to decide on the state's stake in the Butinge oil terminal. The draft project says a single investor cannot have more than 33 percent in the company.

- The new government reduced the number of public servants in the ministries by 1,000, said the minister of administration reform and municipalities, Kestutis Skrebys. to the news conference. He also said that there are plans to cut the number of ministries too although he declined to detail them.
- Conservative MP Romualdas Sikorskis, 71, died after a long and severe desease.
- An opinion poll by Baltic Surveys showed that trust in the government and parliament dropped in February by 11 and 9 percent respectively versus January.
- The statistics department reports that the number of marriages decreased in Lithuania in 1996 by 1,718.
- Foreign debt was $882 million on February 1, the finance ministry said, and it has increased by $200 million during 1996.
- Estonian Prime Minister Tiit Vaehi and his cabinet resigned.

- The reconstruction project of Vilnius Hotel will be discussed by the local council. After an 18 to 24 month reconstruction, the hotel will belong to the Sheraton Hotel chain, the newspaper says. The reconstruction will be carried out by Baltic Funds Hotels and might cost $30-35 million.
